body.p:
When your last favor came
to hand I had almost been numbered with
with the dead, but it was Divine will to
spare me a little longer on earth where
I suppose my mission had not yet been ful
filled; and truly grateful am I for this
consideration (if I may so term it) as it enables
me to feel more sensibly my mortality
which till then, almost with shame I confess
it, thought with a full sense of the power
and greatness of an Adored Creator, I had not
felt, the chill hand of sickness, never lost
a nights rest by my own corporeal com-
plaining and therefore the blessing of a
good constitution and undisturbed health
caused a fearlessness, of which I felt too se-
cure; so my friend ? in this little evil
I feel the good, I am now thank Heaven
quite restored, an from an attack of yellow
fever, of which I had lost all fear; a
few years in this climate tend so to lessen the
the vigor both of mind and body that
I long to embrace dame winter again.

The loss of a fond endearing Mother whose very
existence was a pride to my heart, whose tender
care almost reduced me to a state of childhood

again, in her care I was for five years safe
from care, and climate, at her demise my
heart so faint and weary of life without her
yielding to weather and changes, I became
for a season quite an object of anxiety
to my friends, but again and again I thank
Heaven that am quite restored to former
activity and begin to mingle with kind friends
to dispel the gloom I feared too ungracious
in the sight of Heaven, to whose will I honor
with humble submission praying that in this
great affliction I have atoned for many trans-
gressions.

I have receivd your last few numbers
of Occident regularly, but my volumes are
quite incomplete requiring several numbers
which if I cannot obtain from Mr Lawston,
I shall be much obliged to you make known
to you (God willing) in my next. I have had
several applications for my work and
am entirely out of them a single copy.
on order from England and by a most
favorable opportunity had to pass without
the supply you will therefore greatly oblige
me by sending immediately 4 dozens and
let me know how many copies are on
hand as I think I shall be compelled to
furnish a ? 3d edition and much desire to
get off the 2d entirely. I observed your
? yet spirited reply to Mr Jacobs; your

Philosophic and chaste mind could never have
exchanged ? equally, course and ?
with his; you have therefore though with
the touch of a gentleman and schollar han-
dled him with heavy hand than he had ex-
pected; I did not fail to prove this to your
general reading as opportunity occurred.
I feel that I have not been in proper cor-
respondence with my good and valued friend
of Philadelphia. I nevertheless for yet re-
tain all the warmth, and attachment, I
ever did neither time nor climate can
ever chill the ardent affection for my
beloved friends, to all of whom as you my
? will tell the same as from me
To my friend Mr Abm Hart I shall write at
the closing of this. My loving friend, Miss Gratz
I find is yet exercising all her usual bene-
volence, and still active in promoting and
circulating that invaluable treasure; Education
I yet hope for the day when I shall greet
you all again for as I said in a former letter
to you, though, my Brother his wife, and
family endeavor to make me as comfort-
able as possible, being in case and indeed ? as
yet, what is life without ?fulness; this
is not the country for the single ?
happy and good for Mothers ? families
who have a high duty to perform in the
domestic tracing of their homestead &c &c but
for a mind like mine ever active in public good

to be ? up, (however delightful the
dwelling may be) and only meeting a congregation
on the ?, or be absent from home
half the year, in order to attend divine worth of
in ? and endurance; I therefore am not
happy with all their efforts to make me so.
I have noticed per Occident all the doings? in
our various congregations and read of their
zeal with much soul stirring gratification, ho-
ping once more to be in the field of usefulness
among them. Love to Mrs C tell her I expect
to find her a happy grandma. Be kind enough
to let me know in your next if you have
met with a Mr Joseph Aarons, now Physician
in Philadelphia, studied Theology for a short
time with Dr Raphael at least so he says in his
letters, was professor at Girard College; and as I
believe Professing many things, and performing nothing
however this to yourself; only let me know if you
have filled my sheet and I have finished up
sentiments, so farewell my friend with best
wishes for your happiness I remain

Grandpa's kind regard
to you, his eyes not
yet operated on. Rachel's
kind regards also
